paper_info.title: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity
paper_info.author: Joshua Thong
paper_info.main_thesis: Proposals by de Finetti, Hájek, and Easwaran for differentiating possible from impossible events using conditional credences and subset relations fail because they deliver wrong verdicts for disjoint possible events with equal positive credence.

philosophical_moves.quote: However, an impossible event, denoted by ∅, is also assigned 0 credence, that is, Cr(∅) = 0. Is S therefore equally confident in {i} as in ∅, that is, is she equally confident in ticket i winning as in an impossible event obtaining? To say yes seems counter-intuitive. After all, the former event is still possible, that is, it can still happen, while the latter can never happen.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A concrete example (infinite lottery) where possible events get 0 credence
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Highlights counterintuitive consequence of standard probability theory to motivate need for alternative approaches
philosophical_moves.achievement: Establishes the philosophical problem and makes it vivid for the reader
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Use concrete cases to expose counterintuitive implications of formal theories
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophy where formal theories have counterintuitive consequences
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - makes abstract problem concrete and compelling
philosophical_moves.notes: Classic move of using intuitive cases to motivate theoretical problems
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Of particular interest to this paper are de Finetti (1975: 566–67), Hájek (2012) and Easwaran (2014), who argued that S is more confident in any possible event than in an impossible event but insisted that rational credences remain real-valued... Consider the following proposals. (Proper Containment) A ≺ B iff Cr(A) < Cr(B) or A ⊆ B. (Conditionality) A ≺ B iff Cr(A, A ∪ B) < Cr(B, A ∪ B). (Symmetric Difference) A ≺ B iff Cr(A - B, A∆B) < Cr(B - A, A∆B).
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Survey of relevant literature and identification of common position
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Groups related proposals together to create unified target for criticism
philosophical_moves.achievement: Establishes clear dialectical landscape and specific targets for refutation
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Group similar proposals/positions to create unified target for systematic criticism
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophy for organizing critical engagement
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - provides clear structure for the critical argument to follow
philosophical_moves.notes: Efficient way to handle multiple related targets without repetitive argumentation
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Since [0.1, 0.2] ∼ [0.8, 0.9], [0.1, 0.2) ≺ [0.8, 0.9] for a regular ≼. For a real-valued Cr representing a fair lottery over [0, 1], Cr([0.1, 0.2)) = Cr([0.8, 0.9]) = 0.1... Therefore, according to Proper Containment, Conditionality and Symmetric Difference, [0.1, 0.2) ⊀ [0.8, 0.9], which is the wrong verdict.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Formal constraints on comparative confidence orderings and fair lottery setup
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Constructs specific mathematical case where all three proposals give wrong result
philosophical_moves.achievement: Definitively refutes all three target proposals simultaneously
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Construct precise mathematical case that systematically violates multiple related proposals
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Medium - requires mathematical/formal context but pattern transfers
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - decisive refutation of all targets
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly effective because it refutes multiple proposals at once
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Hereafter, I assume that ≼ respects the following four constraints... (Non-Negativity) ∅ ≼ A. (Non-Triviality) ∅ ≺ Ω. (Transitivity) If A ≼ B and B ≼ C, then A ≼ C. (Comparative Additivity) Let A ∩ C = B ∩ C = ∅. Then A ≼ B iff A ∪ C ≼ B ∪ C. These four constraints are common across all major axiomatizations of comparative confidence orderings...
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Survey of relevant literature on comparative confidence orderings
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Lists widely accepted formal constraints to establish non-controversial foundation
philosophical_moves.achievement: Creates uncontroversial foundation that opponents cannot reject
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Ground criticism in widely accepted formal constraints from the literature
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Medium - works in formal contexts with established literatures
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - makes criticism harder to dismiss
philosophical_moves.notes: Smart dialectical move to ground criticism in opponent's own commitments
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Importantly, the counterexample in the next section is not intended to be a knockdown argument against the position held by the three authors above. After all, for all we know, there may be a fourth proposal that fares better than the three above... While the counterexample in the next section shows that R(Cr, A, B) is not, for instance, the statement 'Cr(A, A ∪ B) < Cr(B, A ∪ B)' as per Conditionality, it still leaves open the possibility that there is some other statement...
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Completed setup of targets for criticism
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Explicitly limits scope of criticism to avoid overreach while maintaining significance
philosophical_moves.achievement: Prevents opponents from dismissing argument as overreaching while preserving critical force
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Preemptively limit scope of criticism to specific targets while acknowledging possibility of alternatives
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophy for managing dialectical expectations
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - shows philosophical sophistication and prevents easy dismissal
philosophical_moves.notes: Demonstrates awareness of dialectical landscape and prevents straw-manning charges
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Having said that, what is clear is that this paper leaves de Finetti (1975), Hájek (2012) and Easwaran (2014) with an important puzzle. If they want to maintain that S's comparative confidence ordering can be represented by nothing more than set-theoretic relations and her real-valued unconditional or conditional credences, then the onus is on them to demonstrate the existence of an appropriate relation R(Cr, A, B)...
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Demonstration that existing proposals fail
philosophical_moves.mechanism: After showing specific failures, shifts burden to opponents to find working alternative
philosophical_moves.achievement: Places constructive burden on opponents while maintaining critical stance
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: After refuting specific proposals, shift burden to opponents to provide working alternative
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophy for managing dialectical burden
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - puts opponents in defensive position
philosophical_moves.notes: Effective way to maintain critical pressure after specific refutations
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Here is a straightforward way of ensuring that A ≺ B, where A and B are the events mentioned in the previous paragraph. We can always require rational credences to be regular. Call Cr regular iff Cr(A) > 0 for all nonempty A in the domain of Cr... But of course, to ensure that rational credences are always regular in turn, the requirement that rational credences are real-valued must be dropped.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Demonstrated failure of target proposals
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows there is a solution to the original problem but at a cost the opponents won't accept
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates understanding of dialectical landscape and reinforces opponents' dilemma
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: After criticism, show alternative solution exists but requires abandoning key commitment
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works where opponents have competing commitments
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - shows sophistication and reinforces the dialectical bind
philosophical_moves.notes: Demonstrates fairness by acknowledging solutions while showing their costs
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: Perhaps they should be content with a partial representation of S's comparative confidence ordering, for example if Cr(A, A ∪ B) < Cr(B, A ∪ B), then A ≺ B; this is just the right-to-left direction of Conditionality. Recall that the counterexample above is against the left-to-right directions of all three proposals in §1. So dropping that direction is one escape route.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Completed counterexample showing failure of biconditionals
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Offers opponents a way to save part of their position by weakening their claims
philosophical_moves.achievement: Shows constructive engagement while maintaining critical force
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: After refuting strong claims, offer weaker versions that might survive criticism
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophy for constructive criticism
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: Medium - shows fairness but may weaken critical impact
philosophical_moves.notes: Balances criticism with constructive suggestions
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: However, my counterexample shows that both replacements are false. This is because [0.8, 0.9] ≻ [0.1, 0.2), yet [0.1, 0.2) ⊈ [0.8, 0.9], Cr([0.8, 0.9]) = Cr([0.1, 0.2)) and Cr([0.8, 0.9], [0.1, 0.2) ∪ [0.8, 0.9]) = Cr([0.1, 0.2), [0.1, 0.2) ∪ [0.8, 0.9]) for a real-valued Cr. Thus Easwaran's attack on the argument above is unsuccessful.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Counterexample already constructed for main targets
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows that same counterexample refutes related argument by same author
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates broader implications of the counterexample
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: After developing counterexample for main target, show it applies to related arguments
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works when counterexamples have multiple applications
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: Medium - adds value but somewhat tangential to main argument
philosophical_moves.notes: Efficient use of same counterexample for multiple targets
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

philosophical_moves.quote: In order to examine proposals put forth by de Finetti (1975), Hájek (2012) and Easwaran (2014), technical notions are needed. Hereafter, let A ≼ B represent the statement 'S is at most as confident in A as in B', where A and B are events. Call ≼ S's comparative confidence ordering. Let F be the domain of ≼... (Definition 1) Let A, B ∈ F. 1. A ∼ B := (A ≼ B) ∧ (B ≼ A)...
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Identification of target proposals needing formal analysis
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Introduces formal notation and definitions needed for precise analysis
philosophical_moves.achievement: Creates framework for rigorous examination of target proposals
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Introduce minimal technical apparatus needed for precise analysis of target claims
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Medium - works in contexts requiring formal precision
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - enables precise analysis
philosophical_moves.notes: Necessary groundwork for formal counterexample construction
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Primitive conditional probabilities, subset relations and comparative regularity

emerging_patterns: Strategic dialectical management: Multiple moves work together to manage opponents' responses (scope limitation, burden shifting, escape routes)
Formal precision as dialectical weapon: Technical apparatus enables decisive counterexamples that are hard to dismiss
Comprehensive target engagement: Rather than attacking proposals piecemeal, groups them for systematic refutation
Constructive criticism: Balances refutation with acknowledgment of alternatives and potential escape routes
Counterexample multiplication: Single well-constructed case serves multiple critical purposes

paper_info.title: Microaggression and ambiguous experience
paper_info.author: Luke Brunning
paper_info.main_thesis: Ambiguity is not constitutive of microaggression but rather an optional aggravating feature, supporting a structural account over Rini's experience-based account.

philosophical_moves.quote: Sarah faces two questions, one concerning the status of this type of remark, the other as a token. Viewed as a type of remark, Sarah can consider its wider social impact, function or meaning in asking 'what does that remark mean?' Viewed as a token statement, Sarah can ask 'what did Mark mean by that?'
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A case where ambiguity about oppression could have multiple sources
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Distinguishes between type-level and token-level interpretation to show ambiguity can exist at different levels
philosophical_moves.achievement: Reveals that Rini's account is underspecified about which kind of ambiguity matters
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When facing an ambiguous concept, distinguish between different levels or types of interpretation that could generate the ambiguity
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable to any concept that can be interpreted at multiple levels
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - precisely identifies a key weakness in the target theory
philosophical_moves.notes: Sets up the foundation for showing ambiguity is not always present or necessary
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: More interestingly, what if Sarah is clear that the question 'Where are you really from?' does help sustain oppression? If so, she does not experience ambiguity in that sense... On Rini's ambiguous-experience account we would have to say Sarah is not a victim of a microaggression. But if not, then how are we to understand, and morally label, what Mark has done?
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A clear case where someone recognizes oppression without ambiguity
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows that the opponent's definition excludes paradigm cases, creating a theoretical gap
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates that requiring ambiguity excludes clear cases of microaggression
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Show that a proposed necessary condition excludes paradigm cases of the phenomenon
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works for any definitional project
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - creates serious pressure on the necessity claim
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly effective because it uses the opponent's own example against them
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: Our intuitions about how to make amends to someone can help us appreciate our action's wrong-making features... Typically, we seem to want microaggressors to realize the social implications of their speech or actions... It would seem strange, I suggest, if Mark's apology were to focus instead on the fact that he caused Sarah to experience ambiguity.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theory about what makes actions wrong
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Uses our practices of apology and repair to test what we really think makes actions wrong
philosophical_moves.achievement: Shows mismatch between Rini's theory and our actual moral practices
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Test a theory about wrongness by examining what we think needs to be apologized for
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Ethics - specifically theories of wrongdoing
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - reveals deep tension between theory and practice
philosophical_moves.originality: Novel application of apology practices as theoretical test
philosophical_moves.notes: Clever use of moral phenomenology to test theoretical claims
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: The ambiguous-experience account risks encompassing Gettier-style cases where someone experiences a remark in an ambiguous way, the remark is actually connected to oppressive structures but the cause of their ambiguity experience is unrelated to oppression and has an external cause.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theory that depends on subjective experience
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows that external factors can produce the required experience for wrong reasons
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates that experience-based accounts can misclassify cases
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When a theory depends on subjective states, show how external factors can produce those states inappropriately
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable to any experience-based theory
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - shows systematic problem with experience-based approaches
philosophical_moves.originality: Creative application of Gettier-case structure to ethics
philosophical_moves.notes: Borrows epistemological techniques for ethical analysis
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: Tom's intervention helps to corroborate the experience of Simone and Jane... But notice that his intervention dispels Simone's sense of ambiguity about what she's experiencing, which, if the ambiguous-experience account is correct, means that Simone is not subject to a microaggression.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theory making wrongness depend on victim's experience
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows how third parties can change the experience and thus change whether wrongness occurred
philosophical_moves.achievement: Reveals that external factors can alter the moral status of past actions
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Test experience-based theories by showing how third parties can change the relevant experience
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Ethics - especially theories depending on victim experience
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - shows counterintuitive implications
philosophical_moves.originality: Novel extension of third-party cases to test definitional boundaries
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly effective because it uses an expert from the oppressed community
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: This is like an account of meaning that seeks to reject the idea that what words mean is determined by the speaker's intentions by suggesting that what words mean is settled by what the hearer infers. It misses out the fact that there can be a meaning to words that is understood in a social context irrespective of intention or what is understood at a particular time.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theory that overcorrects by swinging between extremes
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Uses analogy to philosophy of language to show the methodological error
philosophical_moves.achievement: Reveals that rejecting one extreme shouldn't lead to embracing the opposite extreme
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When someone overcorrects by moving from one extreme to another, use analogy to show the middle ground
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable to any domain with similar structure
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - clearly illustrates the methodological problem
philosophical_moves.notes: Effective because philosophy of language provides clear parallel structure
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: Rini is certainly right that as a matter of good moral practice we should often be reluctant to intervene and challenge the experiences of other people, especially in situations where we are not members of a relevant social group or otherwise lack good standing. But recognition of this fact should not influence our underlying account of what microaggressions are.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: An opponent's objection based on practical or political considerations
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Concedes the practical point but distinguishes it from the theoretical question
philosophical_moves.achievement: Deflects political objection while maintaining theoretical critique
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Distinguish between practical/political considerations and theoretical questions to avoid conflation
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable whenever practical and theoretical considerations might be conflated
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - acknowledges legitimate concern while maintaining argument
philosophical_moves.notes: Shows sensitivity to political dimensions while maintaining philosophical rigor
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: Members of the community, like Tom, can explain the connections between hair-touching, racial stereotypes and other dimensions of oppression and help people view certain token actions as instances of more broadly oppressive types... She might be right to think that she lacks standing to question a Black women's experiences (as I also do), but this might not be true of other Black women or members of other minority groups.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theory that privileges individual experience over community knowledge
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows how community knowledge can correct individual perspectives while respecting standpoint epistemology
philosophical_moves.achievement: Provides alternative that respects oppressed people's expertise without individualism
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When facing individual vs community knowledge tension, show how community members can have standing that outsiders lack
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Social epistemology and ethics of oppression
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - provides constructive alternative to pure individualism
philosophical_moves.originality: Novel application of standpoint epistemology to definitional questions
philosophical_moves.notes: Sophisticated handling of epistemic and political dimensions
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: As a result, it is better to view experiences of ambiguity as an aggravating dimension of many instances of microaggression, and as one of the collective harms that repeated microaggressions can engender within oppressed groups.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A feature that sometimes accompanies a phenomenon but isn't essential
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Reframes a proposed necessary condition as an optional aggravating factor
philosophical_moves.achievement: Preserves insights about ambiguity while rejecting its centrality
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When a feature is important but not essential, reframe it as an aggravating rather than constitutive element
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable to any definitional project
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - charitable way to preserve opponent's insights
philosophical_moves.notes: Shows how to be critical while preserving what's valuable in opponent's view
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

philosophical_moves.quote: Taken together, my argument indirectly supports a structural approach to microaggression. Experiences of ambiguity can still play an aggravating role in making microaggressions worse for some people, but we can capture that insight without suggesting ambiguity is a constitutive feature of microaggression.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Multiple criticisms of one theory and an alternative theory available
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Uses elimination of one theory to provide indirect support for alternative
philosophical_moves.achievement: Supports preferred theory without directly arguing for it
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Support your preferred theory by systematically undermining alternatives
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - applicable whenever there are competing theories
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: Medium - indirect support is weaker than direct argument
philosophical_moves.notes: Conservative approach that focuses on criticism rather than positive argument
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Microaggression and ambiguous experience

emerging_patterns: Systematic case-based testing of necessary conditions through counterexamples
Using moral practices (like apology) to test theoretical claims about wrongness
Exploiting tensions between individual experience and community knowledge
Charitable reframing of opponent's insights while rejecting their central claims
Distinguishing levels of analysis (type vs token, practical vs theoretical) to reveal ambiguities
Using analogies from other philosophical domains to reveal methodological errors

paper_info.title: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties
paper_info.author: Guido Löhr
paper_info.main_thesis: There are two distinct kinds of failure in joint action: failing to do one's part (contribution failure) and failing to respect collaborators (disrespect failure).

philosophical_moves.quote: I identify two kinds of failure in joint action. First, we can fail to 'do our part', that is, fail to contribute to fulfilling the joint intention. Second, we can fail to respect our collaborators. Recognizing the distinct natures of both normative relations helps us overcome a key challenge to a reductionist theory of collective intentionality posed by Margaret Gilbert.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: An existing theoretical debate with competing positions and unresolved problems
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Introduces a fundamental distinction that cuts across existing categories to reframe the entire debate
philosophical_moves.achievement: Provides a new analytical framework that promises to resolve standing theoretical problems
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When faced with theoretical deadlock, introduce a distinction that cuts orthogonally to existing debate categories
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - could work in any area with competing theories and unresolved problems
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - sets up the entire paper's argumentative strategy
philosophical_moves.originality: Novel - this specific distinction hasn't been clearly articulated before
philosophical_moves.notes: Classic philosophical move of introducing a distinction to break theoretical deadlock
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: James and Paula are taking a walk together. James is ranting about the government but quickly realizes that Paula shows signs of discomfort. He immediately apologizes and continues the earlier, more successful, conversation about philosophy. But then James speeds up... Paula is confused. Did James not owe it to her to slow down? Did he not respect her enough to at least say goodbye?
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theoretical distinction that needs concrete illustration
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Creates a detailed, multi-stage narrative that allows different theoretical interpretations to be tested against intuitive responses
philosophical_moves.achievement: Makes abstract theoretical distinctions concrete and intuitive while setting up data for analysis
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Use extended, multi-stage cases that allow different aspects of a theoretical distinction to be illustrated separately
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - provides rich material for subsequent analysis
philosophical_moves.notes: The case is designed to generate multiple failure types in sequence
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: What exactly is the difference between the first and the second kind of failure? At least three features tell them apart. The first is a difference in grounding... The second piece of evidence for a distinction pertains to the observation that both kinds of failures render different reactive attitudes appropriate... A third piece of evidence is that reactive actions like apologizing in response to each failure serve different functions.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A proposed distinction that needs systematic defense
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Organizes evidence into exactly three categories, each providing independent support for the distinction
philosophical_moves.achievement: Creates systematic, memorable support structure while avoiding both under- and over-argumentation
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When defending a conceptual distinction, organize evidence into exactly three independent lines of support
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - provides clear, systematic organization
philosophical_moves.notes: Three seems to be the optimal number for systematic yet memorable argument structure
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: Reactive attitudes like anger and resentment have long been used to track moral wrongdoing (Strawson 2008). Simply disappearing without notification or permission can make moral reactive attitudes and actions appropriate. It would be appropriate for Paula to resent James... In the case of the first failure, it would be inappropriate if Paula were to resent James even before he apologizes and changes the subject.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: An established philosophical tradition connecting reactive attitudes to moral categories
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Uses appropriateness of different reactive attitudes as a diagnostic test for different types of normative failure
philosophical_moves.achievement: Provides an independent criterion for the proposed distinction based on established philosophical theory
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Use appropriateness conditions for reactive attitudes as diagnostic tests for normative distinctions
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: Ethics/moral philosophy primarily, but could extend to other normative domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - leverages established theory to support new distinction
philosophical_moves.originality: Variation - novel application of established technique
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly powerful because it connects to Strawsonian tradition in moral philosophy
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: Did we encounter a difference in degree rather than kind? A simpler explanation might be that we are looking at two failures of the same kind of contralateral commitments... that merely differ in the degree of harm caused, whether or not there was an immediate repair.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A proposed distinction between two phenomena
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Anticipates the natural reductionist objection that apparent differences in kind are really just differences in degree
philosophical_moves.achievement: Shows awareness of standard philosophical objection patterns and sets up defense
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When proposing distinctions in kind, anticipate and address the 'really just degree' objection
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - this objection pattern appears across all philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - essential defensive move
philosophical_moves.notes: Almost mandatory when making kind/degree distinctions in philosophy
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: My response is that such a view would exaggerate the 'wrongness' of an expected and abundant morally innocent type of failure. It would cause an explosion of wronging in joint action. When I do something wrong relative to our joint intention but immediately corrected my behaviour, I make a mistake, but I do not wrong my collaborator.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theoretical position that would classify many ordinary actions as wrongdoing
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows that the opposing view leads to implausible over-classification of ordinary, innocent behavior as morally problematic
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates theoretical costs of not accepting the proposed distinction
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When defending distinctions, show that collapsing them leads to problematic 'explosion' of unwanted classifications
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works wherever over-classification is a concern
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - intuitive and compelling objection
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly effective because it appeals to common-sense intuitions about ordinary behavior
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: To illustrate what I mean, we can flip the original scenario around, as suggested by a reviewer. Imagine that James, instead of changing the topic, continues his rant, causing Paula to feel visibly uncomfortable. However, when he starts walking too fast and Paula tells him to slow down, he slows down immediately and even apologizes. But he keeps ranting.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: An original case that illustrates a distinction
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Creates a modified version of the original case where the elements are rearranged to test whether the distinction still holds
philosophical_moves.achievement: Provides additional evidence for the robustness of the proposed distinction across different configurations
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Test conceptual distinctions by systematically varying elements in your original cases
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: Medium - adds supporting evidence but not dramatically new
philosophical_moves.notes: Good way to stress-test proposed distinctions
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: Therefore another piece of evidence for a difference in kind rather than degree is that we can easily imagine cases of disrespect where the person who disrespects their collaborator never makes the first mistake and contributes extremely well to the joint intention... The simplest example of the phenomenon of disrespect within a well-functioning joint action involves joint actions under coercion.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: Two proposed categories that might be conflated
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows that one category can be maximally present while the other is completely absent, proving their independence
philosophical_moves.achievement: Provides decisive evidence that the categories are truly distinct rather than different aspects of the same phenomenon
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: Prove independence of categories by showing cases where one is maximal and the other minimal/absent
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - provides strong evidence for independence
philosophical_moves.notes: Particularly powerful for showing that proposed distinctions capture genuinely different phenomena
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: The value of the proposed distinction depends on the contribution it can make to the empirical and theoretical debate on normativity in joint action... I argue that Gilbert's intuition of non-moral obligations to do one's part, for example under coercion, tracks the first kind of failure... Thus Bratman can argue that, even if the joint intention no longer exists, we may still owe it to the others to continue
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theoretical distinction that has been defended, and existing theoretical problems
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Shows how the proposed distinction allows existing theoretical positions to handle previously problematic cases
philosophical_moves.achievement: Demonstrates the theoretical utility of the distinction by solving standing problems
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: After defending a conceptual distinction, show how it enables solutions to existing theoretical problems
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works across philosophical domains
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: High - shows practical theoretical value
philosophical_moves.originality: Standard technique for showing theoretical utility
philosophical_moves.notes: Essential for showing that conceptual work has genuine theoretical payoff
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

philosophical_moves.quote: I predict that lay people will share this intuition. My distinction allows us to see that leaving is not a form of wronging (moral or otherwise). Leaving does not require any special justification as there was no obligation to the criminal to begin with.
philosophical_moves.setup_required: A theoretical framework that makes contact with empirical research
philosophical_moves.mechanism: Derives specific empirical predictions from the theoretical distinction to test its adequacy
philosophical_moves.achievement: Makes the theory empirically testable and shows confidence in its predictive power
philosophical_moves.transferable_pattern: When developing theory that connects to empirical work, generate specific testable predictions
philosophical_moves.domain_specificity: General - works wherever theory connects to empirical research
philosophical_moves.effectiveness: Medium - adds empirical dimension but prediction is fairly obvious
philosophical_moves.notes: Important for connecting theoretical work to experimental philosophy
philosophical_moves.source_paper: Two kinds of failure in joint action: On disrespect and directed duties

emerging_patterns: Distinction-based problem solving: Introduce a conceptual distinction to break theoretical deadlock
Multi-staged case construction: Use complex narratives that allow different aspects of a theory to be tested
Systematic defense structure: Organize evidence into exactly three independent lines of support
Diagnostic criteria from established theory: Use appropriateness conditions from existing philosophical traditions as tests
Independence proofs through extreme cases: Show categories are distinct by maximizing one while minimizing the other
Theoretical payoff demonstration: Show how conceptual work solves existing problems in the literature
